hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Not that far. Streets were quiet for once.
I usually stay in and fold origami models. Simple hobby.
Lately, too many checks in the building interrupt even that.
Printouts are harder to come by now, too.
Walk wasn’t bad. Just… different with all these patrols now.
I do origami. Keeps my mind from wandering.
Last time, enforcement ran a sweep just as I finished a model.
Sometimes I use system memos—no one uses paper anymore.
Hard to focus when they’re knocking every night.
Not too long, but getting here takes planning now.
I fold origami at home most evenings—cranes, tessellations, whatever’s complex.
It helps with the stress, especially after the alerts last week.
Hard to find decent paper since the new checks started.
I had to hide my models during a recent security sweep.
Even hobbies feel suspicious lately.
Took longer than usual. Security checkpoints everywhere tonight.
Folding origami models is my thing—complex designs, lots of steps.
After the ghost profile leak, they’ve stepped up surveillance at my place.
I was mid-fold last night when the ID scans started.
I use scrap printouts from work. They're getting scarce now.
I track how often checks disrupt hobbies. It’s almost every night lately.
It’s strange how something so harmless feels risky these days.
Long walk, with two reroutes and a random scan.
Origami is more than a hobby for me—complex folds, mathematical patterns.
I started back in school, but now it’s almost a coping strategy.
After Halden’s death, building security went haywire—models hidden under tablecloths, ID checks mid-fold.
Some of my best models are built from corrupted data memos—there’s a metaphor there.
I keep a log of how disruptions spike after every Council announcement. Patterns emerge.
Nobody really asks why folding paper suddenly feels rebellious.
Sometimes, I wonder if they’d flag a crane or cube as subversive—just because it’s mine.
hobby_answer: Yeah. It does, sometimes.
Mostly just cranes and cubes. Nothing too fancy lately.
Had to hide a few projects after that last hallway sweep.
Hard to focus if you expect a knock any minute.
Everyone’s quiet with their hobbies, for good reason.
Yeah, sometimes it helps. Not as much lately.
Origami gives me something to do when things get tense.
Lost a few projects during those unannounced checks last week.
It’s not safe to leave paper around anymore.
Funny how even folding paper feels suspicious these days.
I keep things simple. Less to explain if anyone asks.
It does, in a way. Calms the static in my head.
I make modular designs. Each fold steers my thoughts somewhere safer.
I used to trade finished pieces with neighbors—now everyone’s too nervous.
Since the ghost profile alerts, enforcement checks have made me pack up quickly.
My last tessellation nearly got swept into someone’s audit inventory.
Trying to keep up the habit, but it’s changed. The city’s just... different.
Folding feels tense lately, not peaceful.
Definitely. I focus on patterns so I don’t spiral.
Started with simple cranes, now I do intricate tessellations.
Used to leave finished models for cleaning staff or neighbors—can’t risk it now.
Since those alerts about ‘ghost’ BCI users, everyone acts like paper is evidence.
Last week, security swept our floor. I had to hide everything mid-fold.
The feeling sticks, like my hobby’s suspicious by default now.
Weird that something so harmless feels dangerous.
But I need it, even if I fold in the dark.
Always did, since I was a kid. Paper was predictable, even when nothing else was.
I taught myself new tessellations—modular units fit together neatly when people don’t.
After Halden’s death, the city’s been crawling with random checks.
Last week I was folding when security swept the whole block for ‘ghost’ signatures.
Had to hide the models—the paper felt almost radioactive after that.
Now I log which patterns I do based on which nights feel safest.
Gave up gifting pieces, even to friends. Too risky—paper trails, literally.
It’s changed how I see everything around me. Even something simple’s uneasy now.
But I still fold. Quiet patterns in chaos—maybe that’s the only control left.
